name: Pioneer Valley Books
description: Your trusted literacy partner for over 25 years, Pioneer Valley Books is dedicated to providing educators with high-quality print and digital resources for comprehensive literacy instruction. We offer engaging books and research-based materials to improve educational outcomes and foster a love of reading. Our robust literacy programs empower educators to create the best possible learning experience for their students.

company_updates_collection.description: Step into our NEW Shared Reading kits! We are so excited to announce that Stepping Together Shared Reading is here! Complete your whole-group classroom literacy program with reading, writing, phonological awareness, and phonics. Learn more: https://bit.ly/3HSn1Od

NEW! We've recently added three brand-new phonics book sets to our fabulous Digital Reader app—72 decodable readers! 

The Ready, Set, Go books provide the most novice reader with opportunities to develop concepts of print, such as one-to-one matching and return sweep, as well as practice in decoding using consonant sounds and short vowels.

The On Our Way books provide the beginning reader with opportunities to practice decoding CVC words, words with initial and final digraphs, and simple words with initial blends.

The Building Up books provide the early reader with opportunities to practice decoding words with final blends, long vowels, and vowel teams. digitalreader.com

The “Science of Reading” (SoR) movement that began in 2018 has gained momentum and has had an outsized influence on state reading policy and classroom practice. However, the SoR movement presents two negative impacts on long-term literacy education—a commitment to the “Simple View” of Reading (SVR) and mandates for phonics-first instruction for all beginning readers. In this webinar, Paul Thomas, Ed.D. (Professor of Education, Furman University, and author of How to End the Reading War and Serve the Literacy Needs of All Students), places the SoR movement within the context of the robust but complex current state of reading science. Come join us on Thursday, October 20, 2022, at 4 p.m. as we explore what’s next in literacy education. Register: https://bit.ly/3qm8aVV 

#education #webinar #literacy #teachers #teaching #reading #teachingresources #professionallearning #scienceofreading

Meet our amazing panel of educators from our free interactive webinar: Starting Strong with Small-Group Instruction! They cannot wait to collaborate with you on back to school tips and thoughts! Register for our free September 8th webinar here: https://bit.ly/3vp2pcd

• Karen Cangemi has 30 years of experience teaching and coaching and, as a former district literacy coach, worked with underperforming schools to close the achievement gap. 

• Andrea Davis has taught all combinations of 5th, 6th 2nd, and 3rd grades. She also stepped into the role of On-site Instructional Coach and was responsible for delivering professional development, supporting teachers in the classroom and with curriculum.

• Allison Jurado taught 4th and 5th grade for seven years.

• Emily Wayman has taught 3rd–5th grades, Reading Recovery, and worked as a District Literacy K–5th Coach. 

• Marcie Hydrick has taught 1st grade for 20 years. 

• Ruben J. Saldivar has taught 2nd grade and 5th grade since 2007. He also worked one-on-one with Autistic children as a Paraeducator. 

• Mackenzie Gallace is a kindergarten teacher in Pinellas County, Florida.

• Deirdre Smith currently teaches 3rd grade.

• Nicole Cropsy is currently an elementary school teacher.

Misty Copeland is an American ballet dancer for American Ballet Theatre. Copeland is the first African American woman to be promoted to a principal dancer in the 75-year history of the American Ballet Theatre. She is also an author of acclaimed children's books! Winning multiple awards: 2015 Coretta Scott King Illustrator Award, 2015 Ezra Jack Keats Book Award New Writer Honor, NPR Best Book of 2014, An Amazon Best Book of 2014 – Ages 6-8, An Amazon Best Book of the Month, September 2014, and Essence Magazine Best Children’s Book of 2014. Today we celebrate Misty!

Shirley Chisholm became the first Black woman elected to Congress. She represented New York's 12th District from 1969 to 1983. In 1972, she was the first woman to run for the Democratic Party’s presidential nomination. Her campaign slogan was "Unbought and Unbossed.” Visit blackhistorymonth.gov for teaching resources. #teaching #teachers #blackhistorymonth #blackhistory #blackhistoryfacts #blackhistoryisamericanhistory

We are bombarded daily with loud headlines, information overload, and endless opinions. It can get overwhelming and confusing! The literacy world is no different. In this free webinar, Dr. Sam Bommarito will take us through some of the media’s misleading information on reading instruction and discuss how research on reading is becoming misconstrued. He will offer ideas for how proponents of the science of reading can find common ground with the proponents of balanced literacy. Register: https://lnkd.in/d7XRkpN

One of the women featured in "Hidden Figures," Dorothy Vaughan spent 28 years as a mathematician and programmer at the Langley Research Center in Virginia. She was the first Black supervisor at NASA and made essential contributions to the space program. She was posthumously awarded the Congressional Gold Medal in 2019.

George Washington Carver was an agricultural scientist and inventor who developed hundreds of uses for peanuts, sweet potatoes and soybeans. He promoted them as alternative crops to cotton as ways to prevent soil depletion and free poor farmers from their dependence on cotton. The George Washington Carver National Monument opened ten years after his death and was the first national monument dedicated to a Black American.

Misty Copeland is an American ballet dancer for American Ballet Theatre. Copeland is the first African American woman to be promoted to a principal dancer in the 75-year history of the American Ballet Theatre. She is also an author of acclaimed children's books! Winning multiple awards: 2015 Coretta Scott King Illustrator Award, 2015 Ezra Jack Keats Book Award New Writer Honor, NPR Best Book of 2014, An Amazon Best Book of 2014 – Ages 6-8, An Amazon Best Book of the Month, September 2014, and Essence Magazine Best Children’s Book of 2014. Today we celebrate Misty!

Preparing for liftoff! Phonics Launch is a 4-day literacy system that provides carefully sequenced, high-impact instruction in phonics. Beautifully illustrated decodable storybooks facilitate practice in phonics skills while introducing readers to engaging stories. Systematic and explicit phonological awareness and phonics activities follow a scope and sequence to ensure students have a strong foundation of basic and complex sound−letter links. The system is flexible and features short 10-minute mini-lessons that can be standalone or supplementary and can be taught in a small-group or whole-group setting. Learn more: http://bit.ly/42bH05W

In Tandem is a small-group 5-day reading program with sequenced, high-impact instruction in reading, writing, phonemic awareness, and phonics. Decodable storybooks are paired with fiction and nonfiction leveled texts to accelerate student learning. A systematic program of daily, explicit phonological awareness and phonics activities ensures students fully grasp basic and complex sound-letter links. Each lesson helps students cultivate vocabulary, develop fluency, improve comprehension, and build critical literacy skills. Engage every student in learning, promote deeper thinking, and inspire them to become powerful and joyful readers! Learn more: https://bit.ly/3JnrooT

She was the first Black supervisor at NASA and made essential contributions to the space program. She was posthumously awarded the Congressional Gold Medal in 2019.

September 15th to October 15th is Hispanic or Latinx Heritage Month. This month is dedicated to recognizing and honoring the contributions of Americans with ancestors from a country that speaks Spanish as the primary language: Mexico, the Caribbean, Central and South America, and Spain. While the official designation for the people being celebrated this month is Hispanic, when it comes to describing identity, many different terms are used. For example, Latino/a or Latinx (a gender-neutral alternative) or one’s family’s Country of Origin, such as Mexican or Cuban American, are acceptable, depending on the individual’s preference. I myself am happy to be referred to as Hispanic, Latina, Chicana, or Mexican American. Checking in with others and seeing how they prefer to be identified is always a great practice!

“We have to get away from the idea that every child in every classroom will benefit from exactly the same approach, even when research suggests that the research does have promise. We owe it to every child to make sure we honor the full range of literacy research in our literacy teaching.”
- Dr. Maren Aukerman

To wrap up your Wednesday, we are thrilled to share Dr. Maren Aukerman’s recent lecture titled "Toward Comprehensive, Research-Informed Literacy Instruction: Thinking With, Against, and Beyond the Science of Reading".

Dr. Maren Aukerman’s research on reading comprehension and teacher-student dialogue challenges viewers to question conventional wisdom on what it means to educate and prioritize the voices of students in the classroom. Here at Pioneer Valley Books, we are grateful for Dr. Aukerman’s thoughtful analysis of the current conversations addressing literacy education practices. We encourage you to invest 90 minutes to soak up the knowledge presented.

🎙️In this thoughtful interview with Dr. Sam Bommarito, Susan Vincent talks about research that suggests the benefit of using multiple types of text in literacy instruction. Susan highlights several highly respected sources as she shares her perspective on text selection, including both decodables and leveled texts. 

📚At Pioneer Valley Books we have always believed that children deserve to read high-quality books during each chapter of their literacy journey. We have been committed to this mission since day one. 

🍏🍎We encourage all practicing teachers to consider Susan’s suggested criteria for book selection. The titles that we choose we put in front of children gives them a message about reading and about what literacy is. That is a big responsibility and we are honored that so many educators trust us to be their partner in literacy.

September 15th to October 15th is Hispanic or Latinx Heritage Month. This month is dedicated to recognizing and honoring the contributions of Americans with ancestors from a country that speaks Spanish as the primary language: Mexico, the Caribbean, Central and South America, and Spain. While the official designation for the people being celebrated this month is Hispanic, when it comes to describing identity, many different terms are used. For example, Latino/a or Latinx (a gender-neutral alternative) or one’s family’s Country of Origin, such as Mexican or Cuban American, are acceptable, depending on the individual’s preference. I myself am happy to be referred to as Hispanic, Latina, Chicana, or Mexican American. Checking in with others and seeing how they prefer to be identified is always a great practice! 

Join PVB in celebrating those who have contributed so much!

New research! 💡 

A study within an Ohio school district was conducted to determine the preliminary relationship between Stepping Together and Phonics Launch and student literacy performance in grades K–2. Results among a closely matched sample of students showed that Stepping Together and Phonics Launch have a positive impact on student literacy performance and can help students gain essential literacy skills at an accelerated rate.

Stepping Together and Phonics Launch students across all grade levels demonstrated significantly higher reading performance as compared to control students. Furthermore, students in kindergarten, grade 1, and grade 2 using Stepping Together and Phonics Launch all demonstrated significantly higher scores in the i-Ready over students that did not use the programs.

Read the full report: https://lnkd.in/e3Mp2Uz2

New research! 💡 

A study within an Ohio school district was conducted to determine the preliminary relationship between Stepping Together and Phonics Launch and student literacy performance in grades K–2. Results among a closely matched sample of students showed that Stepping Together and Phonics Launch have a positive impact on student literacy performance and can help students gain essential literacy skills at an accelerated rate.

Stepping Together and Phonics Launch students across all grade levels demonstrated significantly higher reading performance as compared to control students. Furthermore, students in kindergarten, grade 1, and grade 2 using Stepping Together and Phonics Launch all demonstrated significantly higher scores in the i-Ready over students that did not use the programs.

Read the full report: https://lnkd.in/e3Mp2Uz2

Teacher Tip! 🌱

Phonics meets knowledge building in this tasty classroom activity inspired by our InfoCodables book on edible plants.

Focus on the digraph ch (as in chop and chomp) and follow these simple steps:

1️⃣ Read together
2️⃣ Have each student complete a “mini fact page”
3️⃣ Combine into a class book or bulletin board!

It’s an engaging, collaborative way to reinforce decoding skills while building content-area vocabulary.
